Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Analyze the Request: Input: A pseudo-BPMN representation of a multinational smartphone supply chain process (Market Research -> R&D -> Sourcing (Parallel) -> Shipping -> Assembly -> Quality (Exclusive) -> Packaging -> Shipping (Parallel) -> Customs -> Distribution (Parallel) -> Inventory Monitoring -> Adjustment (Exclusive) -> End). Task: Generate 20 open-ended, thought-provoking questions. Focus Areas: Rationale behind flows, potential improvements, risk management, decision-making, stakeholder communication, and performance measurement. Constraint: No SQL queries.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Analyze the Process (BPMN) to Identify Themes & Pain Points: Phase 1: Market Research & R&D. (Start -> Design) Theme: Alignment with market needs. Phase 2: Sourcing. (Parallel Gateway) Theme: Geographic diversification, supply chain resilience, single points of failure (Taiwan, Japan, etc.), synchronization of deliveries. Phase 3: Manufacturing. (Ship to Malaysia -> Assemble) Theme: Logistics efficiency, 24/7 operations, labor costs. Phase 4: Quality Control. (Exclusive Gateway -> Loop back) Theme: Root cause analysis, cost of rework vs. scrap, automation in QA. Phase 5: Distribution Logistics. (Split: Air/Sea -> Join) Theme: Cost vs. speed, carbon footprint, inventory balancing. Phase 6: Post-Distribution. (Split: Warehouse, Retail, E-commerce, VIP -> Join) Theme: Channel conflict management, omnichannel strategy. Phase 7: Monitoring & Feedback Loop. (Exclusive Gateway: Adjust vs. Proceed) Theme: Agility, data integration, forecasting accuracy.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Drafting Questions (Iterative Process): Category: Rationale & Strategy 1. Why source specific parts from specific countries? (Resilience vs. Cost) 2. Why split logistics between Air and Sea? (Cost/Benefit analysis) Category: Process Improvement & Efficiency 3. How to optimize the Rework loop? (Reduce cycle time) 4. Can the parallel sourcing be synchronized better to avoid holding costs? 5. Automation opportunities in Assembly/QA. Category: Risk Management (Crucial for this specific process) 6. What happens if Taiwan cant supply microprocessors? (Geo-political risk) 7. Single point of failure at the Malaysia plant? 8. Disruptions in shipping lanes (e.g., Panama/Suez). Category: Decision Making (Gateways) 9. Criteria for Pass/Fail in QA. Is it manual or automated data-driven? 10. Criteria for Adjust Orders vs Proceed. How sensitive is the threshold? Category: Stakeholder Communication 11. Coordinating with 4 different suppliers for parallel arrival. 12. Communication between Customs and Distribution centers. Category: Performance Measurement 13. KPIs for the 24/7 assembly. 14. Measuring the success of the Air vs. Sea split. 15. Forecast accuracy metrics.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: Refining and Expanding to reach 20 high-quality questions: Draft 1: How do we handle delays in one parallel sourcing branch? -> Refinement: Given the reliance on distinct geographic suppliers for components, how does the process account for variable lead times to prevent bottlenecks at the assembly plant if one stream is delayed? Draft 2: Why Malaysia? -> Refinement: What specific economic or logistical advantages justify the centralization of assembly in Malaysia versus a distributed manufacturing model closer to the component sources? Draft 3: Rework loop. -> Refinement: How can data captured during the Rework or Scrap phase be fed back into the R&D design phase to minimize failure rates in future product iterations? Draft 4: Air vs Sea split. -> Refinement: In the split between Air Freight and Cargo Ship, what dynamic algorithms determine the allocation ratio to balance inventory urgency with total landed cost and carbon footprint goals? Draft 5: Customs. -> Refinement: Since customs clearance is a linear step after the parallel logistics join, what contingency plans exist to handle regulatory holds that could stall the entire global distribution network? Draft 6: Distribution split. -> Refinement: How do we mitigate channel conflict when simultaneously fulfilling VIP pre-orders, retail distribution, and e-commerce orders from limited inventory stocks? Draft 7: Inventory monitoring. -> Refinement: What specific leading indicators are monitored at the Sales Forecast stage to trigger the Adjust Orders decision before a stock-out or overstock situation becomes critical? Draft 8: Market research. -> Refinement: To what extent does the initial Market Research phase integrate real-time supply chain feasibility analysis, rather than just consumer demand, to set realistic product specs?

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Final Review: Check against constraints: 20 questions? Yes. Open-ended? Yes. Thought-provoking? Yes. Covers all categories (Rationale, Improvements, Risk, Decisions, Communication, Performance)? Yes. No SQL? Yes.
